declarations.comments:
The result of a computation: either `Loop` containing the updated
accumulator, or `Done` containing the final result of the computation.
declarations.title: Step

declarations.comments: Proxy for a `Functor`.
declarations.title: FProxy

declarations.comments:
Match a `VariantF` with a `Record` containing functions for handling cases.
This is similar to `on`, except instead of providing a single label and
handler, you can provide a record where each field maps to a particular
`VariantF` case.

```purescript
onMatch
 { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" id foo
 , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> snd bar
 }
```

Polymorphic functions in records (such as `show` or `id`) can lead
to inference issues if not all polymorphic variables are specified
in usage. When in doubt, label methods with specific types, such as
`show :: Int -> String`, or give the whole record an appropriate type.
declarations.title: onMatch

declarations.comments:
Attempt to read a variant at a given label by providing branches.
The failure branch receives the provided variant, but with the label
removed.
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching using an `onMatch` case record.
```purescript
matchFn :: VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String), baz :: FProxy (Either String)) Int -> String
matchFn = match
 { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo
 , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar)
 , baz: \baz -> "Baz: " <> either id show baz
 }
```
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Inject into the variant at a given label.
```purescript
maybeAtFoo :: forall r. VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe | r) Int
maybeAtFoo = inj (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (Just 42)
```
declarations.title: inj

declarations.comments:
Combinator for partial matching with a default value in case of failure.
```purescript
caseFn :: forall r. VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String) | r) Int -> String
caseFn = default "No match"
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar))
```
declarations.title: default

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching.
```purescript
caseFn :: VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String), baz :: FProxy (Either String)) Int -> String
caseFn = case_
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar))
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "baz") (\baz -> "Baz: " <> either id show baz)
```
declarations.title: case_

declarations.comments: A value-level proxy for a type-level symbol.
declarations.title: SProxy

children.comments:
This instance is provided for compatibility, but is otherwise
unnecessary. You can use monadic recursion with `Run`, deferring the
`MonadRec` constraint till it is interpretted.
children.title: monadRecRun

children.comments:
This will insert an `EFF` effect because `MonadAff` entails `MonadEff`.
If you don't want this, use `Run.liftAff` rather than `Control.Monad.Aff.Class.liftAff`.
children.title: runMonadAff

declarations.comments:
An extensible effect Monad, indexed by a set of effect functors. Effects
are eliminated by interpretation into a pure value or into some base
effect Monad.

An example using `State` and `Except`:
```purescript
type MyEffects =
  ( state ∷ STATE Int
  , except ∷ EXCEPT String
  , eff ∷ EFF (console ∷ CONSOLE)
  )

yesProgram ∷ Run MyEffects Unit
yesProgram = do
  whenM (gets (_ < 0)) do
    throw "Number is less than 0"
  whileM_ (gets (_ > 0)) do
    liftEff $ log "Yes"
    modify (_ - 1)

main =
  yesProgram
    # catch (liftEff <<< log)
    # runState 10
    # runBaseEff
    # void
````
declarations.title: Run

declarations.comments:
Lifts an effect functor into the `Run` Monad according to the provided
`SProxy` slot.
declarations.title: lift

declarations.comments: Enqueues an instruction in the `Run` Monad.
declarations.title: send

declarations.comments: Extracts the value from a purely interpreted program.
declarations.title: extract

declarations.comments:
Extracts the value from a program via some Monad `m`. This assumes
stack safety under Monadic recursion.
declarations.title: interpret

declarations.comments:
Extracts the value from a program via some MonadRec `m`, preserving
stack safety.
declarations.title: interpretRec

declarations.comments:
Identical to `interpret` but with a less restrictive type signature,
letting you intercept the rest of the program.
declarations.title: run

declarations.comments:
Identical to `interpretRec` but with a less restrictive type
signature, letting you intercept the rest of the program.
declarations.title: runRec

declarations.comments: Extracts the value from a program via some `m` using continuation passing.
declarations.title: runCont

declarations.comments:
Eliminates effects purely. Uses `Step` from `Control.Monad.Rec.Class` to
preserve stack safety under tail recursion.
declarations.title: runPure

declarations.comments:
Extracts the value from a program via some Monad `m` with an internal
accumulator. This assumes stack safety under Monadic recursion.
declarations.title: runAccum

declarations.comments:
Extracts the value from a program via some MonadRec `m` with an internal
accumulator.
declarations.title: runAccumRec

declarations.comments:
Extracts the value from a program via some `m` using continuation passing
with an internal accumulator.
declarations.title: runAccumCont

declarations.comments:
Eliminates effects purely with an internal accumulator. Uses `Step` from
`Control.Monad.Rec.Class` to preserve stack safety under tail recursion.
declarations.title: runAccumPure

declarations.comments:
Reflects the next instruction or the final value if there are no more
instructions.
declarations.title: peel

declarations.comments: Eliminator for the `Run` data type.
declarations.title: resume

declarations.comments:
Casts some set of effects to a wider set of effects via a left-biased
union. For example, you could take a closed effect and unify it with
a superset of effects because we know the additional effects never
occur.

```purescript
type LessRows = (foo :: FOO)
type MoreRows = (foo :: FOO, bar :: BAR, baz :: BAZ)

foo :: Run LessRows Unit
foo = foo

foo' :: Run MoreRows Unit
foo' = expand foo
```
declarations.title: expand

declarations.comments: Type synonym for using `Eff` as an effect.
declarations.title: EFFECT

declarations.comments: Type synonym for using `Aff` as an effect.
declarations.title: AFF

declarations.comments: Lift an `Aff` effect into the `Run` Monad via the `aff` label.
declarations.title: liftAff

declarations.comments: Runs a base `Eff` effect.
declarations.title: runBaseEffect

declarations.comments: Runs a base `Aff` effect.
declarations.title: runBaseAff

declarations.comments: Runs base `Aff` and `Eff` together as one effect.
declarations.title: runBaseAff'
